===Among Christians=== The custom of Charon’s obol not only continued into the Christian era,<ref>Marcus Louis Rautman, ''Daily Life in the Byzantine Empire'' (Greenwood Publishing Group, 2006), [https://books.google.com/books?id=hs3iEyVRHKsC&pg=PA11&dq=%22charon%27s+obol%22&lr=&num=100&as_brr=3&sig=ACfU3U1cz05juBN-TdB_2aG24Uyxk3ZW_Q p. 11.]</ref> but was adopted by Christians, as a single coin was sometimes placed in the mouth for [[Christianity|Christian]] burials.<ref>Stevens, "Charon’s Obol," p. 226; G.J.C. Snoek, ''Medieval Piety from Relics to the Eucharist: A Process of Mutual Interaction'' (Leiden 1995), p. 103, with documentation in note 8; [[Ramsay MacMullen]], ''Christianity and Paganism in the Fourth to Eighth Centuries'' (Yale University Press, 1997), sources given [https://books.google.com/books?id=FQqEGf84wMgC&pg=PA218&dq=%22Charon+obol%22&lr=&as_brr=0&sig=ACfU3U2CL4Pcy5M9GFABTlmHGRzm-tfGPA p. 218, note 20]; in Christian graves of 4th-century Gaul, Bonnie Effros, ''Creating Community with Food and Drink in [[Merovingian]] Gaul'' (Macmillan, 2002), p. 82; on the difficulty of distinguishing Christian from traditional burials in 4th-century [[Gaul]], Mark J. Johnson, "Pagan-Christian Burial Practices of the Fourth Century: Shared Tombs?" ''Journal of Early Christian Studies'' 5 (1997) 37–59.</ref> At [[Arcy-Sainte-Restitue]] in [[Picardy]], a Merovingian grave yielded a coin of [[Constantine I]], the first Christian emperor, used as Charon’s obol.<ref>Blaise Pichon, ''L’[[Aisne]]'' (Académie des inscriptions et belles-lettres, 2002), p. 95.</ref> In Britain, the practice was just as frequent, if not more so, among Christians and persisted even to the end of the 19th century.<ref>L. V. Grinsell, "The Ferryman and His Fee" in ''Folklore'' 68 (1957), pp. 265 and 268.</ref> A folklorist writing in 1914 was able to document a witness in Britain who had seen a penny placed in the mouth of an old man as he lay in his coffin.<ref>Ronald Burn, "Folklore from Newmarket, Cambridgeshire" in ''Folklore'' 25 (1914), p. 365.</ref> In 1878, [[Pope Pius IX]] was entombed with a coin.<ref>Thomas Pekáry, "''Mors perpetua est.'' Zum Jenseitsglauben in Rom" in ''Laverna'' 5 (1994), p. 96, cited by [[Ramsay MacMullen]], ''Christianity and Paganism in the Fourth to Eighth Centuries'' (Yale University Press, 1997), pp. 218 (note 20) and 268. The way in which coinage was included in the burial is unclear in MacMullen's reference.</ref> The practice was widely documented around the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries in Greece, where the coin was sometimes accompanied by [[the keys of Pluto|a key]].<ref>Grabka, "Christian Viaticum", p. 13, with extensive references; [[Rennell Rodd, 1st Baron Rennell|Rennell Rodd]], ''The Customs and Lore of Modern Greece'' (D. Stott, 1892), 2nd edition, [https://books.google.com/books?id=A1UbAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA125&dq=%22Charon%27s+obol%22&lr=&num=100&as_brr=3#PPA126,M1 p. 126.]</ref>
==='Ghost' coins and crosses=== {{see also|Exonumia}} [[File:Tetradrachm Athens 450 reverse CdM Paris.jpg|left|thumb|Coin (450s BC) stamped with the '''owl of Athens''']] So-called "ghost coins" also appear with the dead. These are impressions of an actual coin or numismatic icon struck into a small piece of gold foil.<ref>L.V. Grinsell, "The Ferryman and His Fee," ''Folklore'' 68 (1957), p. 263.</ref> In a 5th- or 4th-century BC grave at [[Syracuse, Sicily]], a small rectangular gold leaf stamped with a dual-faced figure, possibly [[Demeter]]/[[Persephone|Kore]], was found in the skeleton’s mouth. In a marble [[cremation]] box from the mid-2nd century BC, the "Charon's piece" took the form of a bit of gold foil stamped with an owl; in addition to the charred bone fragments, the box also contained gold leaves from a wreath of the type sometimes associated with the [[Greco-Roman mysteries|mystery religions]].<ref>Cedric G. Boulter, "Graves in Lenormant Street, Athens," ''Hesperia'' 32 (1963), pp. 115 and 126, with other examples cited. On gold wreaths as characteristic of burial among those practicing the traditional religions, [[Minucius Felix]], ''Octavius'' 28.3–4, cited by Mark J. Johnson, "Pagan-Christian Burial Practices of the Fourth Century: Shared Tombs?" ''Journal of Early Christian Studies'' 5 (1997), p. 45.</ref> Within an Athenian family burial plot of the 2nd century BC, a thin gold disk similarly stamped with the owl of Athens had been placed in the mouth of each male.<ref>T.J. Dunbabin, "Archaeology in Greece, 1939–45," ''Journal of Hellenic Studies'' 64 (1944), p. 80.</ref>
These examples of the "Charon's piece" resemble in material and size the tiny inscribed tablet or funerary amulet called a ''lamella'' (Latin for a metal-foil sheet) or a ''[[Totenpass]]'', a "passport for the dead" with instructions on navigating the afterlife, conventionally regarded as a form of Orphic or Dionysiac [[Devotional medal#History|devotional]].<ref>Roy Kotansky, "Incantations and Prayers for Salvation on Inscribed Greek Amulets," in ''Magika Hiera: Ancient Greek Magic and Religion,'' edited by Christopher A. Faraone and Dirk Obbink (Oxford University Press, 1991), p. 116. [[J. Paul Getty Museum|The Getty Museum]] owns an outstanding example of a 4th-century BC Orphic prayer sheet from Thessaly, a gold-leaf rectangle measuring about 1 by 1½ inches (2.54 by 3.81 cm), that may be viewed [http://www.getty.edu/art/gettyguide/artObjectDetails?artobj=8289&handle=li online.]</ref> Several of these prayer sheets have been found in positions that indicate placement in or on the deceased's mouth. A functional equivalence with the Charon's piece is further suggested by the evidence of flattened coins used as mouth coverings (''epistomia'') from graves in Crete.<ref>Fritz Graf and Sarah Iles Johnston, ''Ritual Texts for the Afterlife: Orpheus and the Bacchic Gold Tablets'' (Routledge, 2007) p. 26 [https://books.google.com/books?id=_TmiaW0uvAgC&pg=PA26&dq=%2216+Mylopotamos%22+intitle:ritual+intitle:Texts+intitle:for+intitle:the+intitle:Afterlife&lr=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online] p. 28 [https://books.google.com/books?id=_TmiaW0uvAgC&pg=PA28&dq=%22reused+flattened+gold%22&lr=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online], and pp. 32, 44, 46, 162, 214.</ref> A gold [[wikt:phylactery|phylactery]] with a damaged inscription invoking the [[syncretism|syncretic]] god [[Serapis|Sarapis]] was found within the skull in a burial from the late 1st century AD in southern Rome. The gold tablet may have served both as a protective amulet during the deceased’s lifetime and then, with its insertion into the mouth, possibly on the model of Charon’s obol, as a ''[[Totenpass]]''.<ref>D.R. Jordan, "The Inscribed Gold Tablet from the Vigna Codini," ''American Journal of Archaeology'' 89 (1985) 162–167, especially note 32; additional description by Campbell Bonner, "An Obscure Inscription on a Gold Tablet," ''Hesperia'' 13 (1944) 30–35.</ref>
[[File:Douris gold piece.jpg|thumb|Gold-leaf oval stamped with female head, from a Roman-era burial in [[Douris (Baalbek)|Douris]], Lebanon ''([[German Archaeological Institute|Deutsches Archäologisches Institut]])'']] In a late Roman-era burial in [[Douris (Baalbek)|Douris]], near [[Baalbek]], [[Lebanon]], the forehead, nose, and mouth of the deceased — a woman, in so far as skeletal remains can indicate — were covered with sheets of gold-leaf. She wore a wreath made from gold oak leaves, and her clothing had been sewn with gold-leaf ovals decorated with female faces. Several [[Roman glass|glass vessels]] were arranged at her feet, and her discoverers interpreted the bronze coin close to her head as an example of Charon’s obol.<ref>[[German Archaeological Institute|Deutsches Archäologisches Institut]], [http://www.dainst.org/index_586_en.html Lebanon, Baalbek-Douris].</ref>
Textual evidence also exists for covering portions of the deceased’s body with gold foil. One of the accusations of [[heresy]] against the [[Phrygia]]n Christian movement known as the [[Montanism|Montanists]] was that they sealed the mouths of their dead with plates of gold like initiates into the [[Greco-Roman mysteries|mysteries]];<ref>J.-B. Chabot, ''Chronique de [[Michael the Syrian|Michel le Syrien]], Patriarque jacobite d’Antioche (1166–99)'', vol. 4 (Paris 1910), cited and discussed by Susanna Elm, "‘Pierced by Bronze Needles’: Anti-Montanist Charges of Ritual Stigmatization in Their Fourth-Century Context," ''Journal of Early Christian Studies'' 4 (1996), p. 424.</ref> factual or not, the charge indicates an anxiety that Christian practice be distinguished from that of other religions, and again suggests that Charon’s obol and the "Orphic" gold tablets could fulfill a similar purpose.<ref>This point was argued by Maria Guarducci, in ''Rendiconti della Pontificia Accademia Romana di Archeologia'' 15 (1939) 87ff, as referenced by Marcus N. Tod, "The Progress of Greek [[Epigraphy]], 1941–1945," ''Journal of Hellenic Studies'' 65 (1945), p. 89.</ref> The [[Early Christianity|early Christian]] poet [[Prudentius]] seems<ref>The [[Textual criticism|text is problematic]] and suffers from some corruption; Maurice P. Cunningham, "Aurelii Prudentii Clementis Carmina", [[Corpus Christianorum]] 126 (Turnholt, 1966), p. 367.</ref> to be referring either to these inscribed gold-leaf tablets or to the larger gold-foil coverings in one of his condemnations of the mystery religions. Prudentius says that ''auri lammina'' ("sheets of gold") were placed on the bodies of initiates as part of funeral rites.<ref>[[Prudentius]], ''Peristephanon'' 10.1071–90; discussion in Susanna Elm, "Pierced by Bronze Needles," ''Journal of Early Christian Studies'' 4 (1996), p. 423.</ref> This practice may or may not be distinct from the funerary use of gold leaf inscribed with figures and placed on the eyes, mouths, and chests of warriors in [[Macedon]]ian burials during the [[Archaic period in Greece|late Archaic period]] (580–460 BC); in September 2008, archaeologists working near [[Pella]] in northern Greece publicized the discovery of twenty warrior graves in which the deceased wore bronze helmets and were supplied with iron swords and knives along with these gold-leaf coverings.<ref>Reported by [[Reuters]] with photo, "Greece unearths treasures at [[Alexander the Great|Alexander]]'s birthplace," and by the [[Associated Press]], "Greek archaeologists unearth jewelry in cemetery," both retrieved via [[Yahoo! News]] on October 5, 2008. AP report via [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] archived [https://www.webcitation.org/5bcNQC8AQ?url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2008/09/080911-gold-photo.html here with photo]; additional photos with Ryan Kiesel’s article, "Greek dig unearths secrets of Alexander the Great’s golden era," ''Mail Online'' September 11, 2008, archived [https://www.webcitation.org/5bcO9ETY1?url=http://www.mailonsunday.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1054631/Greek-dig-unearths-secrets-Alexander-Greats-golden-era.html?printingPage=true here.]</ref>
====''Goldblattkreuze''==== [[File:Tremissis Julius Nepos-RIC 3221.jpg|thumb|A ''tremissis'' of [[Julius Nepos]] with cross on reverse (''5th century'')]] In Gaul and in [[Alamanni|Alemannic]] territory, Christian graves of the Merovingian period reveal an analogous [[Christianization|Christianized]] practice in the form of gold or gold-alloy leaf shaped like a cross,<ref>The British Museum has [https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_image.aspx?image=ps208644.jpg&retpage=20511 an example.]</ref> imprinted with designs, and deposited possibly as [[Votive deposit|votives]] or amulets for the deceased. These paper-thin, fragile gold crosses are sometimes referred to by scholars with the [[German language|German]] term ''Goldblattkreuze''. They appear to have been sown onto the deceased’s garment just before burial, not worn during life,<ref>Bonnie Effros, ''Caring for Body and Soul: Burial and the Afterlife in the [[Merovingian]] World'' (Penn State Press, 2002), pp. 48 and 158, with additional references in note 78.</ref> and in this practice are comparable to the pierced Roman coins found in Anglo-Saxon graves that were attached to clothing instead of or in addition to being threaded onto a necklace.<ref>T.S.N. Moorhead, "Roman Bronze Coinage in Sub-Roman and Early Anglo-Saxon England," in ''Coinage and History in the North Sea World, c. AD 500–1250'' (Brill, 2006), pp. 100–101.</ref>
The crosses are characteristic of [[Lombardy|Lombardic Italy]]<ref>See "Belluno grave group," [[British Museum]], for a [[Lombardy|Lombardic]] [https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_mla/b/belluno_grave_group.aspx example], also [https://www.webcitation.org/5buOLVxFv?url=http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_mla/b/belluno_grave_group.aspx archived.]</ref> ([[Cisalpine Gaul]] of the Roman imperial era), where they were fastened to veils and placed over the deceased's mouth in a continuation of [[Byzantine]] practice. Throughout the Lombardic realm and north into Germanic territory, the crosses gradually replaced [[bracteate]]s during the 7th century.<ref>Herbert Schutz, ''Tools, Weapons, and Ornaments: Germanic Material Culture in Pre-[[Carolingian Empire|Carolingian]] [[Central Europe]], 400–750'' (Brill, 2001), p. 98 [https://books.google.com/books?id=r-DLX9PPEFoC&pg=RA1-PA98&dq=%22placed+over+the+deceased%27s+mouth%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online], with photographic examples figure 54 [https://books.google.com/books?id=r-DLX9PPEFoC&pg=RA1-PA57&dq=%22Goldleaf+crosses+(Freiburg,+Museum+für+Vor-+und+Frühgeschichte%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> The transition is signalled by Scandinavian bracteates found in [[Kent]] that are stamped with cross motifs resembling the Lombardic crosses.<ref>Märit Gaimster, "Scandinavian Gold Bracteates in Britain," ''Medieval Archaeology'' 36 (1992), pp. 20–21.</ref> Two plain gold-foil crosses of [[Christian cross#Forms of the Cross|Latin form]], found in the burial of a 7th-century [[Kingdom of Essex|East Saxon king]], are the first known examples from England, announced in 2004.<ref>[[Museum of London]], "Treasure of a [[Kingdom of Essex|Saxon King of Essex]]: A Recent Discovery at [[Southend-on-Sea]]," with image of gold crosses [http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/archive/exhibits/prittlewell/pages/object_crosses.htm here.]</ref> The king’s other grave goods included glass vessels made in England and two different Merovingian gold coins, each of which had a cross on the reverse.<ref>Museum of London, "Treasure of a Saxon King of Essex," English glass vessels [http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/archive/exhibits/prittlewell/pages/object_glass.htm here] and Merovingian gold coins [http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/archive/exhibits/prittlewell/pages/object_coins.htm here].</ref> Coins of the period were adapted with Christian iconography in part to facilitate their use as an alternative to amulets of traditional religions.<ref>Gareth Williams, "The Circulation and Function of Coinage in Conversion-Period England, ''c.'' AD 580–675," in ''Coinage and History in the North Sea World, c. AD 500–1250'' (Brill, 2006), [https://books.google.com/books?id=X-qvyzsUkRsC&pg=PA166&dq=%22Christian+alternative+to+pagan+amulets%22&lr=&as_brr=0&sig=ACfU3U0g32jo9LSfmDcf6KHb1Da2Uj3p3A pp. 166–167]; fuller discussion of the Christian practice by Mary Margaret Fulghum, "Coins Used as Amulets in Late Antiquity," in ''Between Magic and Religion: Interdisciplinary Studies in Ancient Mediterranean Religion and Society'' (Rowman & Littlefield, 2001), pp. 139–148 [https://books.google.com/books?id=NBQe3gS_ys0C&pg=PA139&dq=%22Ample+attention%22+intitle:Between+intitle:Magic+intitle:and+intitle:Religion&lr=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref>
[[File:SorteMuld guldgubber 600px.jpg|thumb|left|upright|''Gullgubber,'' gold-foil images from Scandinavia (6th–7th century)]]
====Scandinavian ''gullgubber''==== Scandinavia also produced small and fragile gold-foil pieces, called ''[[gullgubber]]'', that were worked in [[repoussé]] with human figures. These begin to appear in the late Iron Age and continue into the Viking Age. In form they resemble the gold-foil pieces such as those found at Douris, but the ''gullgubber'' were not fashioned with a fastening element and are not associated with burials. They occur in the archaeological record sometimes singly, but most often in large numbers. Some scholars have speculated that they are a form of "temple money" or votive offering,<ref>Signe Horn Fuglesang, "Viking and Medieval Amulets in Scandinavia," ''Fornvännen'' 84 (1989), pp. 18–19, figures with examples pp. 20–22.</ref> but Sharon Ratke has suggested that they might represent good wishes for travelers, perhaps as a metaphor for the dead on their journey to the otherworld,<ref>Sharon Ratke, ''Guldgubbe — Einblicke in die Völkerwanderungszeit'' (Dissertation, University of Bonn, 2009),[http://hss.ulb.uni-bonn.de:90/2009/1909/1909-1.pdf] English summary p. 229, and [http://hss.ulb.uni-bonn.de:90/2009/1909/1909.htm abstract.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303104238/http://hss.ulb.uni-bonn.de:90/2009/1909/1909.htm |date=2012-03-03 }}</ref> especially those depicting "[[Ghost#Terminology|wraith]]s."<ref>Sharon Radke and Rudolf Simek, "Gullgubber: Relics of Pre-Christian Law Rituals?," in ''Old Norse Religion in Long-Term Perspectives: Origins, Changes, and Interactions'' (Nordic Academic Press, 2006), pp, 262–263 (see also "Interpretations" [http://www.guldgubber.de/interpretations.html online.]</ref>
==Religious significance== Ships often appear in Greek and Roman funerary art representing a voyage to the [[Fortunate Isles|Isles of the Blessed]], and a 2nd-century [[sarcophagus]] found in [[Velletri]], near Rome, included Charon’s boat among its subject matter.<ref>Marion Lawrence, "Ships, Monsters and Jonah," ''American Journal of Archaeology'' 66 (1962), p. 291, note 9.</ref> In modern-era Greek [[folklore|folkloric]] survivals of Charon (as Charos the death demon), sea voyage and river crossing are [[conflation|conflated]], and in one later tale, the soul is held hostage by pirates, perhaps representing the oarsmen, who require a ransom for release.<ref>John Cuthbert Lawson, ''Modern Greek Folklore and Ancient Greek Religion: A Study in Survivals'' (Cambridge University Press, 1910), p. 108.</ref> The [[mytheme]] of the passage to the afterlife as a voyage or crossing is not unique to Greco-Roman belief nor to [[Proto-Indo-Europeans|Indo-European]] culture as a whole, as it occurs also in [[ancient Egyptian religion]]<ref>See, for instance, article on the Egyptian god [[Aken (god)|Aken]].</ref> and other belief systems that are culturally unrelated.<ref>Grabka, "Christian Viaticum," pp. 2–3. Influence can be hard to establish or disprove; Raymond A. Dart, "Death Ships in South West Africa and South-East Asia," ''South African Archaeological Bulletin'' 17 (1962) 231–234, thought it possible that African carved "ships of the dead" were influenced by Egyptian beliefs or even the concept of Charon’s ferry. To illustrate the difficulty of establishing influence, the discovery of an 8th-century BC [[stele]] in present-day [[Turkey]], announced in November 2008, is regarded as indicating the "dynamics of cultural contact and exchange in the borderlands of antiquity where Indo-European and Semitic people interacted in the Iron Age", as reported by John Noble Wilford, "Found: An Ancient Monument to the Soul," ''New York Times'' (November 18, 2008), [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/18/science/18soul.html?_r=2&8dpc&oref=slogin online.]</ref> The boatman of the dead himself appears in diverse cultures with no special relation to Greece or to each other.<ref>[[Bruce Lincoln]], "The Ferryman of the Dead," ''Journal of Indo-European Studies'' 8 (1980) p. 41; Lincoln’s purpose at the time was to establish the [[Centum-Satem isogloss|centum-satem]] bifurcation of the [[Proto-Indo-European religion|Proto-Indo-European]] ferryman [[mytheme]], and he does not discuss payment of a fee. For a very concise summary on the Indo-European afterlife, see Benjamin W. Fortson IV, "The Afterlife," in ''Indo-European Language and Culture: An Introduction'' (Blackwell Publishing, 2004), [https://books.google.com/books?id=5hOtPBF6XWwC&pg=PA25&dq=%22body+of+water+to+an+afterlife%22+intitle:Indo-European&lr=&as_brr=0&sig=ACfU3U32HH97dusQRmC0xRtw7hmqZBSwYg p. 25.]</ref> A [[Sumer]]ian model for Charon has been proposed,<ref name="Sourvinou-Inwood, p. 313">Sourvinou-Inwood, ''"Reading" Greek Death'', p. 313.</ref> and the figure has possible antecedents among the Egyptians; scholars are divided as to whether these influenced the tradition of Charon, but the 1st-century BC historian [[Diodorus Siculus]] thought so and mentions the fee.<ref>[[Diodorus Siculus]], 1.92.2 and 1.96.8; so too Grabka, "Christian Viaticum," pp. 2–3; skepticism from [[Bruce Lincoln]], "The Ferryman of the Dead," ''Journal of Indo-European Studies'' 8 (1980), p. 41.</ref> It might go without saying that only when coinage comes into common use is the idea of payment introduced,<ref>L.V. Grinsell, "The Ferryman and His Fee," ''Folklore'' 68 (1957), pp. 258–261.</ref> but coins were placed in graves before the appearance of the Charon myth in literature.<ref>Stevens, "Charon’s Obol," p. 227.</ref>
Because of the diversity of religious beliefs in the Greco-Roman world, and because the [[Greco-Roman mysteries|mystery religions]] that were most concerned with the [[afterlife]] and [[soteriology]] placed a high value on secrecy and arcane knowledge, no single [[theology]]<ref>See [[Friedrich Solmsen]], "Greek Ideas of the Hereafter in Virgil’s Roman Epic," ''Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society'' 112 (1968) 8–14, especially pp. 9–11 on cautions regarding the "Orphic" label; more extended discussion by Radcliffe G. Edmonds III, ''Myths of the Underworld Journey: [[Plato]], [[Aristophanes]], and the ‘Orphic’ Gold Tablets'' (Cambridge University Press, 2004), limited preview [https://books.google.com/books?id=I_YkMvUVoyYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=intitle:myths+intitle:of+intitle:the+intitle:Underworld+intitle:Journey&lr=&as_brr=0&source=gbs_summary_r&cad=0 here.]</ref> has been reconstructed that would account for Charon’s obol. [[Franz Cumont]] regarded the numerous examples found in Roman tombs as "evidence of no more than a traditional rite which men performed without attaching a definite meaning to it."<ref>[[Franz Cumont]], ''Oriental Religions in Roman Paganism: Lectures Delivered at Yale University as the [[Silliman lecture]]s'' (Yale University Press, 1922), [https://books.google.com/books?id=EdQoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA84&dq=%22performed+without+attaching%22+inauthor:Franz+inauthor:Cumont&lr=&num=50&as_brr=3 p. 84.]</ref> The use of a coin for the rite seems to depend not just on the myth of Charon, but also on other religious and mythic traditions associating wealth and the underworld.<ref>Keld Grinder-Hansen, "Charon’s Fee in Ancient Greece?" ''Acta Hyperborea'' 3 (1991), p. 215.</ref>
===Death and wealth=== [[File:Dionysos Ploutos BM F68.jpg|left|thumb|Dionysus and Ploutos ("Wealth") with the [[Cornucopia|horn of abundance]], 4th century BC]] In cultures that practiced the rite of Charon’s obol, the infernal ferryman who requires payment is one of a number of underworld deities associated with wealth. For the Greeks, [[Pluto (mythology)|Pluto]] (''Ploutōn'', Πλούτων), the ruler of the dead and the consort of [[Persephone]], became [[conflation|conflated]] with [[Plutus]] (''Ploutos'', Πλοῦτος), wealth [[Personification|personified]]; [[Plato]] points out the meaningful ambiguity of this etymological play in his [[dialogue]] ''[[Cratylus]]''.<ref>[[Plato]], ''[[Cratylus]]'' 403a. The interpretation is expressed by [[Socrates]] as one of the interlocutors. The ''Cratylus'' deals extensively with etymology.</ref> [[Hermes]] is a god of boundaries, travel, and [[liminality]], and thus conveys souls across the border that separates the living from the dead, acting as a [[psychopomp]], but he was also a god of exchange, commerce, and profit.<ref name="Sourvinou-Inwood, p. 313"/> The name of his [[interpretatio graeca|Roman counterpart]] [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]] was thought in antiquity to share its derivation with the Latin word ''merces'', "goods, merchandise."<ref>In antiquity, the most common etymology was ''a mercibus'', from ''merces'' ("merchandise"); see Michael Paschalis, ''Virgil's Aeneid'' (Oxford University Press, 1997), p. 58 [https://books.google.com/books?id=o5-3qxjL6lgC&pg=RA1-PA58&dq=etymology+name+Mercurius&lr=&num=100&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] In ''De civitate Dei'', [[Augustine of Hippo|St. Augustine]] proposes an etymology from ''medius currens'', "running in the middle," explaining that "language 'runs' like a sort of mediator between men'"; cited by Antoine Faivre, ''The Eternal Hermes'' (Red Wheel/Weiser, 1995), p. 82 [https://books.google.com/books?id=9A2UMwrR12kC&pg=PA82&dq=etymology+name+Mercurius&lr=&num=100&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref>
The numerous [[chthonic]] deities among the Romans were also frequently associated with wealth. In his treatise ''[[De natura deorum|On the Nature of the Gods]]'', Cicero identifies the Roman god [[Dis Pater]] with the Greek Pluton,<ref>''Diti patri … qui dives ut apud Graecos Πλούτων'' ("Father Dis who, being rich, is Pluto among the Greeks"), ''[[De natura deorum]]'' 2.66.</ref> explaining that riches are hidden in and arise from the earth.<ref>E.J. Kenney, text, translation and commentary, ''Cupid and Psyche'' (Cambridge University Press, 1990), p. 214.</ref> Dis Pater is sometimes regarded as a chthonic [[Saturn (mythology)|Saturn]], ruler of the [[Golden Age#The Golden Age in Europe: Greece|Golden Age]], whose consort [[Ops]] was a goddess of abundance.<ref>H.S. Versnel, ''Inconsistencies in Greek and Roman Religion'', vol. 2 (Brill, 1993), p. 175 ''et passim''.</ref> The obscure goddess [[Angerona]], whose [[iconography]] depicted silence and secrecy,<ref>Susan Savage, "Remotum a Notitia Vulgari," ''Transactions and Proceedings of the American Philological Association'' 76 (1945) p. 164, note 38.</ref> and whose festival followed that of Ops, seems to have regulated communications between the realm of the living and the underworld;<ref>H.S. Versnel, ''Inconsistencies in Greek and Roman Religion'', vol. 2 (Brill, 1993), p. 168, with reference to [[Hendrik Wagenvoort]], "Diva Angerona," ''Mnemosyne'' 9 (1941) 215–217 and (1980) 21–24, reprinted in ''Pietas: Selected Studies in Roman Religion'' (Brill, 1980) [https://books.google.com/books?id=xWaOxU28Nn4C&pg=PA21&dq=%22Angerona+was+a+goddess%22+inauthor:Wagenvoort&lr=&as_brr=0 online.]</ref> she may have been a guardian of both arcane knowledge and stored, secret wealth.<ref>Eva Fiesel, "Etruscan ''ancar''," ''Language'' (1935) 122–128, argued for an [[Etruscan language|Etruscan]] etymology for the goddess’s name from ''ancar'', "wealth," but this is a minority view.</ref> When a Roman died, the treasury at the Temple of [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]] in the [[lucus|sacred grove]] of the funeral goddess [[Libitina]] collected a coin as a "death tax".<ref>Dionysius Halicarnassus 4.15.5; Plutarch, ''Roman Questions'' 23; Lawrence Richardson, ''A New Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome'' (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1992), p. 409; Donald G. Kyle, ''Spectacles of Death in Ancient Rome'' (Routledge, 1998, 2001), p. 166.</ref>
The [[Roman Republic|Republican]] poet [[Ennius]] locates the "treasuries of Death" across the [[Acheron]].<ref>Ennius, ''Acherontem nunc obibo, ubi mortis thesauri obiacent'' ("I will cross the [[Acheron]], where the treasuries of death lie hidden"), from the lost tragedy ''[[Iphigenia]]''; the line is spoken by the protagonist as she faces the prospect of becoming a human sacrifice. The phrase "treasures of Death" is original to the Latin poet’s elaboration of his Greek model; see [[Eduard Fraenkel]], ''Plautine Elements in Plautus'', translated by Tomas Drevikovsky and Frances Muecke (Oxford University Press, 2007; originally published in German 1922), p. 121 [https://books.google.com/books?id=g2WNwu7OR7QC&pg=PA121&dq=Ennius+Acheron+Iphigenia&lr=&as_brr=3 online.]</ref> Romans threw an annual offering of coins into the [[Lacus Curtius]], a pit or chasm in the middle of the [[Roman Forum]]<ref>See entry on "Lacus Curtius" from [[Samuel Ball Platner|Platner]] and [[Thomas Ashby|Ashby]], ''[[A Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome]]'', Bill Thayer’s edition with photos at [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/Places/Europe/Italy/Lazio/Roma/Rome/_Texts/PLATOP*/Lacus_Curtius.html LacusCurtius.]</ref> that was regarded as a ''[[Lapis manalis#Gate to the underworld|mundus]]'' or "port of communication" with the underworld.<ref>Robert Maxwell Ogilvie, ''A Commentary on [[Livy]] Books 1–5'' (Oxford 1965), pp. 75–76. Like a ''mundus'', a tomb was also regarded as an opening between the realms death and life: Stevens, "Charon’s Obol," p. 228; Daniel Ogden, ''Greek and Roman Necromancy'' (Princeton University Press, 2001) ''passim''.</ref>
[[File:Autel de Reims.jpg|right|300px|thumb|The horned god [[Cernunnos]] holding his sack of abundance (food, or coins?), flanked by [[Apollo]] and [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]], with a bull and stag below; the creature in the pediment above is a [[rat]].]] [[Chthonic]] wealth is sometimes attributed to the Celtic horned god of the [[Cernunnos]] type,<ref>Stevens, "Charon’s Obol," p. 228.</ref> one of the deities proposed as the divine progenitor of the [[Gauls]] that [[Julius Caesar]] [[interpretatio graeca#Roman version|identified]] with [[Dis Pater]].<ref>"The Gauls assert that they are all progeny of Father Dis and they say this is handed down by the [[druid]]s" (''Galli se omnes ab Dite patre prognatos praedicant idque ab druidibus proditum dicunt'', ''[[Commentarii de Bello Gallico|Bellum Gallicum]]'' 6.18.1). The 19th-century [[Celtic studies|Celticist]] [[John Rhys]] was an early proponent of Cernunnos in this role — his view is summarized in Harold Peake, "Horned Deities," ''Man'' 22 (1922), pp. 28–29 — but other candidates are [[Sucellus]], the god depicted with a mallet or ''[[Olla (Roman pot)|olla]]'', and [[Toutatis|Teutates]]; see Phyllis Fray Bober, "Cernunnos: Origin and Transformation of a Celtic Divinity," ''American Journal of Archaeology'' 55 (1951) 13–51.</ref> On a [[relief]] from the Gallic ''[[civitas]]'' of the [[Remi]],<ref>[[Émile Espérandieu]], ''Recueil général des bas-reliefs, statues et bustes de la Gaule romaine'' (Paris 1910), no. 3653.</ref> the god holds in his lap a sack or purse, the contents of which — identified by scholars variably as coins or food (grain, small fruits, or nuts)<ref>Miranda J. Green, "God in Man’s Image: Thoughts on the Genesis and Affiliations of Some Romano-British Cult-Imagery," ''Britannia'' 29 (1998), p. 27; Phyllis Fray Bober, "Cernunnos: Origin and Transformation of a Celtic Divinity," ''American Journal of Archaeology'' 55 (1951) 13–51; Harold Peake, "Horned Deities," ''Man'' 22 (1922), p. 28.</ref> — may be intentionally [[Ambiguity|ambiguous]] in expressing desired abundance. The antler-horned god appears on coins from Gaul and Britain, in explicit association with wealth.<ref>Miranda J. Green, "God in Man’s Image," ''Britannia'' 29 (1998), p. 23, with reference to G.C. Boon, "A Coin with the Head of the Cernunnos," ''Seaby Coin and Medal Bulletin'' 769 (1982) 276–282. Since religious iconography is common on coins, this is perhaps not strong evidence for Cernunnos as a god of wealth.</ref> In his best-known representation, on the problematic [[Gundestrup Cauldron]], he is surrounded by animals with mythico-religious significance; taken in the context of an accompanying scene of initiation, the horned god can be interpreted as presiding over the process of [[metempsychosis]], the cycle of death and rebirth,<ref>[[John T. Koch]], ''Celtic Culture: A Historical Encyclopedia'' (ABC-Clio, 2005), p. 856 [https://books.google.com/books?id=f899xH_quaMC&pg=PA856&dq=%22bath+of+eternity%22&lr=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online]; also F. Kaul, "Gundestrup," in ''Reallexikon der germanischen Altertumskunde'' (de Gruyter, 1999), vol. 13, p. 201 [https://books.google.com/books?id=v7Y2N6PBiZcC&pg=PA201&dq=%22bath+of+eternity%22&lr=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> regarded by ancient literary sources as one of the most important tenets of [[Celtic polytheism|Celtic religion]]<ref>[[Julius Caesar]], ''[[Commentarii de Bello Gallico|Bellum Gallicum]]'' 4.13–14; [[Pomponius Mela]], ''Chorographia'' 3.2.18; [[Iamblichus]], ''Life of Pythagoras'' 30; [[Valerius Maximus]], 2.6.10–11; [[Marcus Annaeus Lucanus|Lucan]], ''[[Pharsalia|Bellum Civile]]'' 1.453ff and 448ff. and [[scholium|scholiast]]; [[Diodorus Siculus]] 5.28; [[Strabo]] 4.4.4.</ref> and characteristic also of [[Pythagoreanism]] and the [[Orphism (religion)|Orphic]] or [[Dionysus|Dionysiac]] [[Greco-Roman mysteries|mysteries]].<ref>For initiation and the Gundestrup Cauldron, see Kim R. McCone, "[[Werewolf|Werewolves]], [[Cyclops|Cyclopes]], ''Díberga'', and ''[[Fianna|Fíanna]]'': Juvenile Delinquency in Early Ireland," ''Cambridge Medieval Celtic Studies'' 12 (1986) 1–22.</ref>
From its 7th-century BC beginnings in western [[Anatolia]], ancient coinage was viewed not as distinctly secular, but as a form of communal trust bound up in the ties expressed by religion. The earliest known coin-hoard from [[classical antiquity|antiquity]] was found buried in a pot within the foundations of the [[Temple of Artemis]] at [[Ephesus]], dating to the mid-6th century BC. The iconography of gods and various divine beings appeared regularly on coins issued by Greek cities and later by Rome.<ref>Jonathan Williams, "Religion and Roman Coins," in ''A Companion to Roman Religion'', edited by [[Jörg Rüpke]] (Blackwell Publishing, 2007), p. 143.</ref> The effect of monetization on religious practice is indicated by notations in [[Attic calendar|Greek calendars of sacrifices]] pertaining to fees for priests and prices for offerings and victims. One fragmentary text seems to refer to a single obol to be paid by each initiate of the [[Eleusinian Mysteries]] to the priestess of [[Demeter]], the symbolic value of which is perhaps to be interpreted in light of Charon’s obol as the initiate’s gaining access to knowledge required for successful passage to the afterlife.<ref>John K. Davies, "Temples, Credit, and the Circulation of Money," in ''Money and Its Uses in the Ancient Greek World'' (Oxford University Press, 2004) p. 120 [https://books.google.com/books?id=35g0fewTrXoC&pg=PA120&dq=Money+and+Its+Uses+in+the+Ancient+Greek+World+%22tendency+to+monetize%22&lr=&as_brr=0 online.] See also Michael Vickers, "Golden Greece: Relative Values, [[Mina (unit)|Minae]], and Temple Inventories," ''American Journal of Archaeology'' 94 (1990) 613–625.</ref>
[[Erwin Rohde]] argued, on the basis of later folk customs, that the obol was originally a payment to the dead person himself, as a way of compensating him for the loss of property that passed to the living, or as a token substitute for the more ancient practice of consigning his property to the grave with him. In Rohde's view, the obol was later attached to the myth of the ferryman as an ''ex post facto'' explanation.<ref>[[Erwin Rohde]], ''Psyche: The Cult of Souls and the Belief in Immortality Among the Greeks'' (Routledge 1925; republished 2000), pp. 245–246 [https://books.google.com/books?id=EsVTr_6c7E0C&pg=PA245&dq=obol+%22symbolical+vestige%22&lr=&as_brr=0 online.]</ref>
In the view of [[Richard Seaford]], the introduction of coinage to Greece and the theorizing about [[Value (philosophy)|value]] it provoked was concomitant with and even contributed to the creation of Greek [[metaphysics]].<ref>[[Richard Seaford]], "Reading Money: Leslie Kurke on the Politics of Meaning in Ancient Greece," ''Arion'' 9 (2002) 145–165, introducing ideas developed in ''Money and the Early Greek Mind: Homer, Philosophy, Tragedy'' (Cambridge University Press, 2004).</ref> [[Plato]] criticizes common currency as "polluting", but also says that the guardians of [[The Republic (Plato)|his ideal republic]] should have divine gold and silver money from the gods always present in their souls.<ref>[[Plato]], ''[[The Republic (Plato)|Republic]]'' 417a and 416e.</ref> This Platonic "money in the soul" holds the promise of "divinity, homogeneity, unchanging permanence, self-sufficiency, invisibility."<ref>Richard Seaford, "Reading Money," ''Arion'' 9 (2002), p. 163.</ref>
===The coin as food or seal=== Attempts to explain the symbolism of the rite also must negotiate the illogical placement of the coin in the mouth. The Latin term ''viaticum'' makes sense of Charon’s obol as "sustenance for the journey," and it has been suggested that coins replaced offerings of food for the dead in Roman tradition.<ref>Stevens, "Charon’s Obol," p. 220.</ref>
This dichotomy of food for the living and gold for the dead is a theme in the myth of [[Midas|King Midas]], versions of which draw on elements of the [[Dionysian mysteries]]. The [[Phrygia]]n king's famous "golden touch" was a divine gift from Dionysus, but its acceptance separated him from the human world of nourishment and reproduction: both his food and his daughter were transformed by contact with him into immutable, unreciprocal gold. In some versions of the myth, Midas's hard-won insight into the meaning of life and the limitations of earthly wealth is accompanied by conversion to the [[cult of Dionysus]]. Having learned his lessons as an initiate into the mysteries, and after ritual immersion in the river [[Pactolus]], Midas forsakes the "bogus eternity" of gold for spiritual rebirth.<ref>Richard Seaford, ''Money and the Early Greek Mind: Homer, Philosophy, Tragedy'' (Cambridge University Press, 2004), pp. 143, 150, 259, 284, 306–308, limited preview [https://books.google.com/books?id=kU6xx-DAgFgC&pg=PP1&dq=intitle:Money+intitle:and+intitle:the+intitle:Early+intitle:Greek+intitle:Mind&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0 online.]</ref>
John Cuthbert Lawson, an early 20th-century folklorist whose approach was influenced by the [[Cambridge Ritualists]], argued that both the food metaphor and the coin as payment for the ferryman were later rationalizations of the original ritual. Although single coins from [[inhumation]]s appear most often inside or in the vicinity of the skull, they are also found in the hand or a pouch, a more logical place to carry a payment.<ref name="John Cuthbert Lawson 1910 pp. 108">John Cuthbert Lawson, ''Modern Greek Folklore and Ancient Greek Religion'' (Cambridge University Press, 1910), pp. 108–114.</ref> Lawson viewed the coin as originally a seal, used as potsherds sometimes were on the lips of the dead to block the return of the soul, believed to pass from the body with the last breath. One of the first steps in preparing a corpse was to seal the lips, sometimes with linen or gold bands, to prevent the soul’s return.<ref>Stevens, "Charon’s Obol," p. 221.</ref> The stopping of the mouth by Charon's obol has been used to illuminate burial practices intended, for instance, to prevent [[vampire]]s or other [[Revenant (folklore)|revenants]] from returning.<ref>For discussion, see the article on [[Vampire]]s, particularly "[[Vampire#Creating vampires|Creating vampires]]" and "[[Vampire#Protection|Protection]]."</ref>
[[File:Eye Horus Louvre Sb3566.jpg|right|thumb|Earthenware ''[[Eye of Horus|uadjet]]'']] The placement of the coin on the mouth can be compared to practices pertaining to the disposition of the dead in the Near East. An Egyptian custom is indicated by a burial at [[Abydos, Egypt|Abydos]], dating from the [[Twenty-second dynasty of Egypt|22nd Dynasty]] (945–720 BC) or later, for which the deceased woman's mouth was covered with a [[faience]] ''[[Eye of Horus|uadjet]]'', or protective eye amulet.<ref>''Mistress of the House, Mistress of Heaven: Women in Ancient Egypt'' (Cincinnati Art Museum, 1996), p. 74 [https://books.google.com/books?id=1pkH3QP390gC&pg=PA74&dq=%22placed+over+the+deceased%27s+mouth%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref> Oval mouth coverings, perforated for fastening, are found in burials throughout the Near East from the 1st century BC through the 1st century AD, providing evidence of an analogous practice for sealing the mouths of the dead in regions not under Roman Imperial control. [[Bahrain]]i excavations at the necropolis of [[Al Hajar Mountains|Al-Hajjar]] produced examples of these coverings in gold leaf, one of which retained [[lip|labial]] imprints.<ref>Pierre Lombard, "Jewellery and Goldware," in ''Traces of Paradise: The Archaeology of Bahrain 2500 BC-300 AD: An Exhibition at the Brunei Gallery, Thornhaugh Street, London WC1, 12 July-15 September 2000'' (I.B. Tauris, 2000), p. 180. These are viewable [https://books.google.com/books?id=7qk_3PwXaycC&pg=PA180&dq=%22placed+over+the+deceased%27s+mouth%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&num=100&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref>
A coin may make a superior seal because of its iconography; in the Thessalian burial of an initiate described [[Charon's obol#Hellenized world|above]], for instance, the coin on the lips depicted the [[Apotropaic magic|apotropaic]] device of the Gorgon’s head. The seal may also serve to regulate the speech of the dead, which was sometimes sought through rituals for its prophetic powers, but also highly regulated as dangerous; mystery religions that offered arcane knowledge of the afterlife prescribed ritual silence.<ref>Discussed at length by John Cuthbert Lawson, ''Modern Greek Folklore and Ancient Greek Religion'' (Cambridge University Press, 1910), [https://books.google.com/books?id=KwE-AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA108&dq=Charon+%22general+oblivion%22+intitle:Greek+inauthor:Lawson&lr=&as_brr=0 pp. 108–114.] Rituals for communicating with the dead or by means of the dead discussed ''passim'' by Daniel Ogden, ''Greek and Roman Necromancy'' (Princeton University Press, 2001). See also Keld Grinder-Hansen, "Charon’s Fee in Ancient Greece?" ''Acta Hyperborea'' 3 (1991), p. 215. Eric A. Ivison presented the paper "Charon’s Obol or [[Apotropaic magic|Apotropaic]] [[Amulet|Talisman]]? Coins in medieval [[Byzantine]] Graves" at a [[Round table (discussion)|round table]] on ritual and ceremony during the International Byzantine Congress, held August 2001 in Paris. For silence in religious ceremonies of antiquity, particularly the mysteries, see N.J. Richardson, ''The [[Homeric Hymns|Homeric Hymn]] to Demeter'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1974), on 2.478–9 as cited by E.J. Kenney, text, translation and [[Commentary (philology)|commentary]], ''Cupid and Psyche'' (Cambridge University Press, 1990), p. 214, referring to Apuleius, ''Metamorphoses'' 6.18, [[Charon's obol#The catabasis of Psyche|below]].</ref> A golden key ''(chrusea klês)'' was laid on the tongue of initiates<ref>[[Sophocles]], ''[[Oedipus at Colonus]]'' 1051 ("Rites they to none betray, /Ere on his lips is laid / Secrecy's golden key / By their own acolytes, / Priestly [[Eumolpidae]]," in the 1912 translation of F. Storr), as cited by [[Jane Ellen Harrison]], introduction to ''Mythology and Monuments of Ancient Athens'', a translation of [[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]] by Margaret de G. Verrall (London, 1890), pp. liv–lv.</ref> as a symbol of the revelation they were obligated to keep secret.<ref>Robert Turcan, ''Les religions de l'Asie dans la vallée du Rhône'' (Brill, 1972), p. 26.</ref> "Charon's obol" is often found in burials with objects or inscriptions indicative of mystery cult, and the coin figures in a Latin prose narrative that alludes to initiation ritual, the "Cupid and Psyche" story from the ''Metamorphoses'' of Apuleius.
===The catabasis of Psyche=== {{for|a synopsis of Apuleius's narrative|Cupid and Psyche}}
In the 2nd-century "Cupid and Psyche" narrative by Apuleius, Psyche, whose name is a Greek word for "soul," is sent on an underworld quest to retrieve the box containing [[Proserpina]]’s secret beauty, in order to restore the love of Cupid. The tale lends itself to multiple interpretational approaches, and it has frequently been analyzed as an [[Cupid and Psyche#As Platonic allegory|allegory of Platonism]] as well as of religious initiation, iterating on a smaller scale the plot of the ''Metamorphoses'' as a whole, which concerns the protagonist Lucius’s journey towards [[salvation]] through the cult of [[Isis]].<ref>Sophia Papaioannou, "Charite’s Rape, Psyche on the Rock and the Parallel Function of Marriage in Apuleius’ ''Metamorphoses''," ''Mnemosyne'' 51 (1998), pp. 302–303, citing G.B. Conte, ''History of Latin Literature'' (Chapel Hill 1994); R. Merkelbach, ''Roman und Mysterium in der Antike'' (Munich and Berlin 1962); and P.G. Walsh, ''The Roman Novel: The'' Satyricon ''of Petronius and the'' Metamorphoses ''of Apuleius'' (Cambridge 1970); see also R. Thibau, "Les Métamorphoses d’Apulée et la théorie platonicienne de l’Erôs," ''Studia Philosophica Gandensia'' 3 (1965) 89–144.</ref> Ritual elements were associated with the story even before Apuleius’s version, as indicated in visual representations; for instance, a 1st-century BC [[sardonyx]] [[cameo (carving)|cameo]] depicting the wedding of Cupid and Psyche shows an attendant elevating a ''[[Winnowing#In Greek culture|liknon]]'' (basket) used in Dionysiac initiation.<ref>Eva Keuls, "Mystery Elements in Menander’s ''Dyscolus''," ''Transactions and Proceedings of the American Philological Association'' 100 (1969), pp. 214–215, further citations in notes 26 and 27. The cameo is in the collections of the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]], information [http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/cameo-with-the-wedding-of-cupid-and-psyche-or-an-initiation-rite-155692 online.]</ref> C. Moreschini saw the ''Metamorphoses'' as moving away from the [[Platonism]] of Apuleius’s earlier ''Apology'' toward a vision of mystic salvation.<ref>C. Moreschini, "La demonologia medioplatonica et le ''Metamorfosi'' di Apuleio," ''Maia'' 17 (1965) 30–46, cited by Carl Schlam, "Platonica in the ''Metamorphoses'' of Apuleius," ''Transactions and Proceedings of the American Philological Association'' 101 (1970), pp. 477–478, note 2.</ref>
[[File:Psyche-Waterhouse.jpg|thumb|upright|''Psyche Opening the Golden Box'' (1903) by the [[pre-Raphaelite]] artist [[John William Waterhouse]]]] Before embarking on her [[Descent to the underworld|descent]], Psyche receives [[Totenpass|instructions for navigating the underworld]]:
{{cquote|The airway of [[Dis Pater|Dis]] is there, and through the yawning gates the pathless route is revealed. Once you cross the threshold, you are committed to the unswerving course that takes you to the very [[Regia]] of [[Orcus (mythology)|Orcus]]. But you shouldn’t go emptyhanded through the shadows past this point, but rather carry cakes of honeyed barley in both hands,<ref>Cakes were often offerings to the gods, particularly in [[Eleusinian Mysteries|Eleusinian religion]]; cakes of barley meal moistened with honey, called ''prokonia'' (προκώνια), were offered to Demeter and Kore at the time of first harvest. See Allaire Brumfield, "Cakes in the ''liknon'': Votives from the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore on Acrocorinth," ''Hesperia'' 66 (1997) 147–172.</ref> and transport two coins in your mouth. … Pass by in silence, without uttering a word. Without further delay you’ll come to the river of the dead, where Prefect Charon demands the toll (''portorium'') up front before he’ll ferry transients in his stitched boat<ref>"Stitched" = ''sutilis'', used also by [[Vergil]] to describe Charon’s boat; Lionel Casson, "Sewn Boats (Virgil, ''Aen''. vi.413–14)," ''Classical Review'' 13 (1963) 257–259. Disagreeing with those who say the boat was either woven of plant material or sewn from hides (see article on the [[Kayak#History|historical kayak]]), Casson compares boats made of sewn planks as documented in antiquity from Mediterranean Africa and elsewhere.</ref> to the distant shore. So you see, even among the dead greed lives,<ref>On greed among the dead, see also Vergil, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text.jsp?doc=Verg.+G.+2.492&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0058 ''Georgics'' 2.492], "the loud roar of greedy Acheron"; also Statius, [http://www.theoi.com/Text/StatiusThebaid4.html ''Thebaid'' 4.474,] "realms of insatiable Death."</ref> and Charon, that collection agent of Dis, is not the kind of god who does anything without a [[Tip (gratuity)|tip]]. But even when he’s dying, the poor man’s required to make his own way (''viaticum … quaerere''), and if it happens that he doesn’t have a penny (''[[Roman Republican currency#Cast bronze coinage|aes]]'') at hand, nobody will give him permission to draw his last breath. To this nasty old man you’ll give one of the two coins you carry — call it boat fare (''naulum'') — but in such a way that he himself should take it from your mouth with his own hand.<ref>[[Apuleius]], ''Metamorphoses'' 6.18, Latin text at the [http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/apuleius/apuleius6.shtml#18 Latin Library].</ref>}}
The two coins serve the plot by providing Psyche with fare for the return; allegorically, this return trip suggests the soul’s rebirth, perhaps a Platonic reincarnation or the divine form implied by the so-called Orphic gold tablets. The myth of Charon has rarely been interpreted in light of mystery religions, despite the association in Apuleius and archaeological evidence of burials that incorporate both Charon’s obol and cultic paraphernalia. And yet "the image of the ferry," [[Helen King (classicist)|Helen King]] notes, "hints that death is not final, but can be reversed, because the ferryman could carry his passengers either way."<ref>[[Helen King (classicist)|Helen King]], review of ''Charon and the Crossing: Ancient, Medieval and Renaissance Transformations of a Myth'' by [[Ron Terpening|Ronnie H. Terpening]] (Associated University Presses, 1985), in ''Classical Review'' 36 (1986) 355–356.</ref> A funeral rite is itself a kind of initiation, or the transition of the soul into another stage of "life."<ref>James M. Redfield, ''The Locrian Maidens: Love and Death in Greek Italy'' (Princeton University Press, 2003), p. 375 [https://books.google.com/books?id=9d7S-rcAyo0C&pg=PA375&dq=%22Death+also+is+a+life+stage%22+intitle:Locrian&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=0#v=onepage&q=%22Death%20also%20is%20a%20life%20stage%22%20intitle%3ALocrian&f=false online.]</ref>
===Coins on the eyes?=== Contrary to popular [[Etiology#Mythology|etiology]] there is little evidence to connect the myth of Charon to the custom of placing a pair of coins on the eyes of the deceased, though the larger gold-foil coverings discussed [[Charon's obol#'Ghost' coins and crosses|above]] might include pieces shaped for the eyes.<ref>An example was found in the Macedonian warrior burials reported in 2008, and may be viewed [https://www.webcitation.org/5bcO9ETY1?url=http://www.mailonsunday.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1054631/Greek-dig-unearths-secrets-Alexander-Greats-golden-era.html?printingPage=true online.]</ref> Pairs of coins are sometimes found in burials, including cremation urns; among the collections of the [[British Museum]] is an urn from Athens, ''ca.'' 300 BC, that contained cremated remains, two obols, and a terracotta figure of a mourning [[Siren (mythology)|siren]].<ref>[[British Museum]], [https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/gr/t/terracotta_funerary_urn.aspx "Terracotta funerary urn."]</ref> Ancient Greek and Latin literary sources, however, mention a pair of coins only when a return trip is anticipated, as in the case of Psyche’s catabasis, and never in regard to sealing the eyes.
Only rarely does the placement of a pair of coins suggest they might have covered the eyes. In [[Judea]], a pair of silver [[denarius|denarii]] were found in the eye sockets of a skull; the burial dated to the 2nd century A.D. occurs within a Jewish community, but the religious affiliation of the deceased is unclear. Jewish ritual in antiquity did not require that the eye be sealed by an object, and it is debatable whether the custom of placing coins on the eyes of the dead was practiced among Jews prior to the modern era.<ref>Review of textual and archaeological evidence by Rachel Hachlili and Ann Killebrew, "Was the Coin-on-Eye Custom a Jewish Burial Practice in the [[Second Temple]] Period?" ''Biblical Archaeologist'' 46 (1983) 147–153; also Rachel Hachlili, ''Jewish Funerary Customs, Practices and Rites in the Second Temple Period'' (Brill, 2005), pp. 437–443, especially p. 440. Regarding the coins found by Hachlili, this emphatic denial: "Nothing suggests that the coins as found by her were originally put upon the eyelids of the corpse, nor does such a custom exist at the time at all," in a letter to the editor by L.Y. Rahmani, chief curator of the Israel Department of Antiquities and Museums, ''Biblical Archaeologist'' 43 (1980), p. 197, and "Roman Coins and the Shroud," ''Biblical Archaeologist'' 45 (1982) 6–7.</ref> During the 1980s, the issue became embroiled with the controversies regarding the [[Shroud of Turin]] when it was argued that the eye area revealed the outlines of coins; since the placement of coins on the eyes for burial is not securely attested in antiquity, apart from the one example from Judea cited above, this interpretation of evidence obtained through digital image processing cannot be claimed as firm support for the shroud's authenticity.<ref>William Meacham, "On the Archaeological Evidence for a Coin-on-Eye Jewish Burial Custom in the First Century A.D.," ''Biblical Archaeologist'' 49 (1986) 56–59, citing evidence from the Shroud of Turin and offering a detailed critique of the methodology and interpretations presented by Hachlili and Killibrew; rejoinder by Hachlili and Killebrew, "The Coin-in-Skull Affair," pp. 59–60, dismissing the question of the shroud and stressing Meacham’s "misunderstanding of the archaeological data"; additional argument by L.Y. Rahmani, "‘Whose Likeness and Inscription Is This?’ (Mark 12:16)," pp. 60–61. See [[Shroud of Turin#Image analysis]].</ref>
[[File:Roman - Pendant with Portrait of Alexander the Great - Walters 57526.jpg|thumb|left|Fourth-century pendant with the image of Alexander the Great ''([[Walters Art Museum]])'']]
===Coins at the feet=== Coins are found also at the deceased’s feet,<ref>Rachel Hachlili and Ann Killebrew, "Was the Coin-on-Eye Custom a Jewish Burial Practice in the [[Second Temple]] Period?" ''Biblical Archaeologist'' 46 (1983), p. 151.</ref> although the purpose of this positioning is uncertain. [[John Chrysostom]] mentions and disparages the use of coins depicting [[Alexander the Great]] as amulets attached by the living to the head or feet, and offers the Christian cross as a more powerful alternative for both salvation and healing:
{{cquote|And what is one to say about them who use charms and amulets, and encircle their heads and feet with golden coins of Alexander of Macedon. Are these our hopes, tell me, that after the cross and death of our Master, we should place our hopes of salvation on an image of a Greek king? Dost thou not know what great result the cross has achieved? It has abolished death, has extinguished [[sin]], has made [[Hades]] useless, has undone the power of the [[devil]], and is it not worth trusting for the health of the body?<ref>[[John Chrysostom]], ''Instructions to [[Catechumen]]s'', Second Instruction 171, [[Christian Classics Ethereal Library]] edition [http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf109.ix.iii.html online]; discussed by Mary Margaret Fulghum, "Coins Used as Amulets in Late Antiquity," in ''Between Magic and Religion'' (Rowman & Littlefield, 2001), p. 144.</ref>}}
==Christian transformation== [[File:Knight-Death-and-the-Devil.jpg|right|thumb|upright|The [[quest]]ing or [[Hunting#Hunting in pastoral and agricultural societies|hunting]] [[knight]] risked dying without a '''[[viaticum]]''' (engraving by [[Albrecht Dürer|Dürer]], ''Knight, Death and the Devil)'']] With instructions that recall those received by Psyche for her heroic descent, or the inscribed ''[[Totenpass]]'' for initiates, the Christian protagonist of a 14th-century French [[pilgrimage]] narrative is advised:
{{cquote|This bread (''[[:fr:Pain|pain]]'', i.e. the Eucharist) is most necessary for the journey you have to make. Before you can come to the place where you will have what you desire, you will go through very difficult straits and you will find poor lodgings, so that you will often be in trouble if you do not carry this bread with you.<ref>[[Guillaume de Deguileville]], ''Le Pelerinage de la vie humaine'', translated by Eugene Clasby (New York 1992), p. 45, in Benjamin Brand, "''Viator ducens ad celestia'': Eucharistic Piety, Papal Politics, and an Early Fifteenth-Century Motet," ''Journal of Musicology'' 20 (2003), p. 263.</ref>}}
[[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] and [[Hiberno-Scottish mission|early–medieval Irish missionaries]] took the idea of a [[viaticum]] literally, carrying the [[Eucharist]]ic bread and oil with them everywhere.<ref>G.J.C. Snoek, ''Medieval Piety from Relics to the Eucharist: A Process of Mutual Interaction'' (Leiden 1995), pp. 94–95.</ref>
The need for a viaticum figures in a [[mythology|myth]]-tinged account of the death of King [[William II of England]], told by the [[Anglo-Normans|Anglo-Norman]] [[chronicle]]r [[Geoffrey Gaimar]]: dying from a battle wound and delirious, the desperate king kept calling out for the ''corpus domini'' (Lord’s body) until a huntsman<ref>The hunter as a figure of [[mythology|myth]] (such as [[Orion (mythology)|Orion]] and [[Actaeon]]) and of [[folklore]] and [[fairy tale]] (as in "[[The Water of Life (German fairy tale)|The Water of Life]]," "[[Donkey Cabbages]]," and "[[Snow White#Story outline|Snow White]]") has a vast literature; see also the [[Wild Hunt]], especially [[Wild Hunt#Leader of the Wild Hunt|Leader of the Wild Hunt]].</ref> acted as priest and gave him flowering herbs as his viaticum.<ref>[[David Crouch (historian)|David Crouch]], "The Troubled Deathbeds of Henry I’s Servants: Death, Confession, and Secular Conduct in the Twelfth Century," ''Albion'' 34 (2002), p. 28, citing ''[[L'Estoire des Engleis]]'', ed. A. Bell (Anglo-Norman Text Society 1960), book 2, lines 6329–40.</ref> In the dominant [[William II of England#Death in the New Forest|tradition of William's death]], he is killed while hunting on the second day of [[Red Deer|red stag]] season, which began August 1, the date of both [[Lughnasadh]] and the [[Calendar of saints|Feast]] of [[San Pietro in Vincoli|St. Peter's Chains]].<ref>Frank Barlow, ''William Rufus'' (Yale University Press, 2nd ed. 2000), p. 420 [https://books.google.com/books?id=DShVaFa2n8IC&pg=PA420&dq=%22No+one+would+have+been+surprised+that+William%22&lr=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.] On the season, see ''[[The Master of Game]] by Edward, Second Duke of York: The Oldest English Book on Hunting'', ed. W.A. and F. Baillie-Grohman, with a foreword by [[Theodore Roosevelt]] (New York: 1909), p. 215 [https://books.google.com/books?id=_acZAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA215&dq=%22GREASE+TIME%22+intitle:master+intitle:of+intitle:game&lr=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online.]</ref>
The hunt is also associated with the administering of a herbal viaticum in the medieval ''[[Chanson de geste|chansons de geste]]'', in which traditional heroic culture and Christian values interpenetrate. The ''chansons'' offer multiple examples of grass or foliage substituted as a viaticum when a warrior or [[knight]] meets his violent end outside the Christian community. [[Sarah Kay]] views this substitute rite as communion with the [[René Girard|Girardian]] "primitive sacred," speculating that "pagan" beliefs lurk beneath a Christian veneer.<ref>Sarah Kay, "The Life of the Dead Body: Death and the Sacred in the [[Chanson de geste|chansons de geste]]," ''Yale French Studies'' 86 (1994), p. 98. [[René Girard]] himself has stated that his work shows "that Judaism and Christianity exist in a continuity with archaic religions" (interview with Grant Kaplan, ''First Things: The Journal of Religion, Culture, and Public Life'', November 6, 2008, [http://www.firstthings.com/onthesquare/?p=1215 online] and [https://www.webcitation.org/5cHGs9GFv?url=http://www.firstthings.com/onthesquare/?p%3D1215 archived]).</ref> In the ''[[Raoul de Cambrai]]'', the dying Bernier receives three blades of grass in place of the ''corpus Domini.''<ref>''Trois fuelles d’erbe … /… por corpus domini'': ''[[Raoul de Cambrai]]'', lines 8257-8258, edited and translated by Sarah Kay (Oxford University Press 1992), pp. 490–491.</ref> Two other ''chansons'' place this desire for communion within the [[mytheme]] of the sacrificial [[Boar hunting#History|boar hunt]].<ref>The religious significance of the [[Wild Boar#Mythology, religion, history and fiction|boar in the traditional religions of Europe]] is evidenced by frequent boar imagery in the [[Celtic art]] of [[Iron Age|Iron-Age]] Europe, for which see John T. Koch, ''Celtic Culture: An Historical Encyclopedia'', vol. 1 (ABC-Clio, 2006), [https://books.google.com/books?id=f899xH_quaMC&pg=PA218&dq=%22artistic+representations+of+boars%22+inauthor:Koch&lr=&as_brr=0 pp. 218–219], and in [[Boar hunting#History|Greco-Roman myths of boar hunting]], particularly the death of [[Adonis#Birth and death of Adonis|Adonis]]. See also articles on the [[Calydonian Boar]] and the [[Erymanthian Boar]].</ref> In ''[[Daurel et Beton]]'', Bove is murdered next to the [[Boar#Mythology, religion, history and fiction|boar]] he just killed; he asks his own killer to grant him communion "with a leaf,"<ref>''[[Daurel et Beton]]'', edited by Arthur S. Kimmel, Studies in the Romance Languages and Literatures 108 (University of North Carolina Press, 1971), line 428, as cited by Sarah Kay, "The Life of the Dead Body," ''Yale French Studies'' 86 (1994), p. 98.</ref> and when he is denied, he then asks that his enemy eat his heart instead. This request is granted; the killer partakes of the victim’s body as an alternative [[sacrament]]. In ''[[Garin le Loherain|Garin le Loheren]]'', Begon is similarly assassinated next to the corpse of a boar, and takes communion with three blades of grass.<ref>''[[Garin le Loherain|Garin le Loheren]]'', edited by Josephine Elvira Vallerie (Michigan, 1947), line 10313ff., especially line 10621, as cited by Sarah Kay, "The Life of the Dead Body," ''Yale French Studies'' 86 (1994), pp. 98–99.</ref>
Kay’s conjecture that a pre-Christian tradition accounts for the use of leaves as the viaticum is supported by evidence from Hellenistic magico-religious practice, the continuance of which is documented in Gaul and among Germanic peoples.<ref>For example, J.H.G. Grattan and Charles Singer, ''Anglo-Saxon Magic and Medicine. Illustrated Specially from the Semi-Pagan Text Lacnunga'' (Oxford University Press, 1952); Felix Grendon, ''Anglo-Saxon Charms'' (Folcroft Library, 1974), ''passim'' (Grendon is most interested, however, in the interpenetration of Christian elements and traditional magic); Anne van Arsdall, ''Medieval Herbal Remedies: The'' Old English Herbarium ''and Anglo-Saxon Medicine'' (Routledge, 2002), [https://books.google.com/books?id=ITxsaqEmVHAC&pg=PA52&dq=%22anglo-saxon+magic%22&lr=&num=50&as_brr=3#PPA53,M1 p. 52ff.], with cautions about disentangling various strands of the magical tradition; Karen Louise Jolly, "Locating the Charms: Medicine, Liturgy, and Folklore," in ''Popular Religion in Late Saxon England'' (University of North Caroline Press, 1996), [https://books.google.com/books?id=P7LqtqbohIsC&pg=PA96&dq=%22glimpse+into+the+intermingling%22+intitle:Late+intitle:Saxon+intitle:England+inauthor:Jolly&lr=&as_brr=0 p. 96ff.]</ref> Spells from the [[Greek Magical Papyri]] often require the insertion of a leaf — an actual leaf, a [[papyrus]] scrap, the representation of a leaf in metal foil, or an inscribed rectangular ''lamella'' (as described [[Charon's obol#'Ghost' coins and crosses|above]]) — into the mouth of a corpse or skull, as a means of conveying messages to and from the realms of the living and the dead. In one spell attributed to Pitys the Thessalian, the practitioner is instructed to inscribe a [[flax]] leaf with [[Ephesia Grammata|magic words]] and to insert it into the mouth of a dead person.<ref>[[Greek Magical Papyri]] IV.2140–44; Daniel Ogden, ''Greek and Roman [[Necromancy]]'' (Princeton University Press 2001), pp. 211–215.</ref>
The insertion of herbs into the mouth of the dead, with a promise of resurrection, occurs also in the Irish tale "The Kern in the Narrow Stripes," the earliest written version of which dates to the 1800s but is thought to preserve an oral tradition of early Irish myth.<ref>J.A. MacCullough, ''[[The Mythology of All Races]]: Celtic and Slavic'' (Boston 1918), vol. 3, p. 60 [https://books.google.com/books?id=-pYYAAAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA60&dq=%22their+powers+survived%22&lr=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online], says the story demonstrates "how the memory of the Tuatha Dé Danann and their powers survived into later centuries."</ref> The kern of the title is an otherworldly [[trickster]] figure who performs a series of miracles; after inducing twenty armed men to kill each other, he produces herbs from his bag and instructs his host's gatekeeper to place them within the jaws of each dead man to bring him back to life. At the end of the tale, the mysterious visitor is revealed as [[Manannán mac Lir]], the Irish god known in other stories for his herd of pigs that offer eternal feasting from their self-renewing flesh.<ref>For translations, see Standish H. O'Grady, ''Silva gadelica (I–XXXI)'' (London 1892), pp. 311–324 full text [https://books.google.com/books?id=G-QGAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA311&dq=%22story+of+the+kern+in+the+narrow+stripes%22&lr=&as_brr=0&as_pt=ALLTYPES online], or the less archaizing Lady Gregory, Part I Book IV: Manannan at Play, from ''Gods and Fighting Men'' (1904), Sacred Texts edition [http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/celt/gafm/gafm19.htm online.]</ref>
===Sacrament and superstition=== Scholars have frequently<ref>Grabka, "Christian Viaticum," pp. 1–43; A. Rush, ''Death and Burial in Christian Antiquity'' (Washington, D.C. 1941), pp. 93–94; Frederick S. Paxton, ''Christianizing Death'' (Cornell University Press 1990), pp. 32–33; G.J.C. Snoek, ''Medieval Piety from Relics to the Eucharist'' (Leiden 1995), ''passim'', but especially pp. 103 and 122–124; Paul Binski, ''Medieval Death: Ritual and Representation'' (Cornell University Press 1996), p. 32; J. Patout Burns, "Death and Burial in Christian Africa: The Literary Evidence," paper delivered to the North American Patristics Society, May 1997; ''et al.''</ref> suggested that the use of a [[viaticum]] in the Christian rite for the dying reflected preexisting religious practice, with Charon’s obol replaced by a more acceptably Christian sacrament. In one [[miracle|miraculous]] story, recounted by [[Pope Innocent III]] in a letter dated 1213, the coins in a moneybox were said literally to have been transformed into [[Eucharist|communion wafers]].<ref>Gavin I. Langmuir, "The Tortures of the Body of Christ," in ''Christendom and Its Discontents'' (Cambridge University Press, 1996), p. 298. Content advisory: the story has an [[Antisemitism|anti-Semitic]] theme, as the moneybox belonged to a Jew who was persuaded consequently to convert.</ref> Because of the viaticum’s presumed pre-Christian origin, an [[anti-Catholicism|anti-Catholic]] historian of religion at the turn of the 18th–19th centuries [[propaganda|propagandized]] the practice, stating that "it was from the [[Paganism|heathens]] [that] the [[papist]]s borrowed it."<ref>William Hurd, ''A New Universal History of the Religious Rites, Ceremonies, and Customs of the Whole World … together with the History of the Reformed Churches'' (Blackburn 1799), [https://books.google.com/books?id=YnEAAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA552&dq=%22it+was+from+the+heathens+the+papists+borrowed+it%22&lr=&as_brr=0 p. 552.]</ref> Contemporary scholars are more likely to explain the borrowing in light of the deep-seated conservatism of burial practices or as a form of religious [[syncretism]] motivated by a psychological need for continuity.<ref>For example, Grabka, "Christian Viaticum," pp. 25ff.; G.J.C. Snoek, ''Medieval Piety from Relics to the Eucharist'' (Leiden 1995), pp. 103 and 122–124; Tamila Mgaloblishvili, ''Ancient Christianity in the Caucasus'' (Routledge, 1998), p. 35.</ref>
[[File:Simone Martini 044.jpg|thumb|200px|Contrary to Church doctrine, the [[communion wafer]] was sometimes placed in the mouth of those already dead as a '''[[viaticum]]''' for the journey]] Among Christians, the practice of burying a corpse with a coin in its mouth was never widespread enough to warrant condemnation from the Church, but the substitute rite came under official scrutiny;<ref>The [[Diocese|Diocesan]] [[Synod#Roman Catholic usage|Synod]] of [[Auxerre]] (561–605), for instance, banned the burying of the eucharistic wafer with the dead; see Bonnie Effros, ''Caring for Body and Soul'' (Penn State Press, 2002), p. 45.</ref> the viaticum should not be, but often was, placed in the mouth after death, apparently out of a [[superstition|superstitious]] desire for its magical protection.<ref>Grabka, "Christian Viaticum," pp. 25-38, and on administering the rite to those already dead pp. 38–42; G.J.C. Snoek, ''Medieval Piety from Relics to the Eucharist'' (Leiden 1995), pp. 103, 122–124; Edward T. Cook, ''A Popular Handbook to the Greek and Roman Antiquities in the British Museum'' (London 1903), pp. 370–371.</ref> By the time Augustine wrote his ''Confessions'', "African bishops had forbidden the celebration of the eucharist in the presence of the corpse. This was necessary to stop the occasional practice of placing the eucharistic bread in the mouth of the dead, a viaticum which replaced the coin needed to pay Charon’s fare."<ref>J. Patout Burns, "Death and Burial in Christian Africa," [http://people.vanderbilt.edu/~james.p.burns/chroma/burial/Burnsburial.html paper] delivered to the North American Patristics Society, May 1997.</ref> [[Pope Gregory I]], in his biography of [[Benedict of Nursia]], tells the story of a [[Monk#Western Christianity|monk]] whose body was twice ejected from his tomb; Benedict advised the family to restore the dead man to his resting place with the viaticum placed on his chest. The placement suggests a functional equivalence with the ''[[Charon's obol#Goldblattkreuze|Goldblattkreuze]]'' and the Orphic gold tablets; its purpose — to assure the deceased’s successful passage to the afterlife — is analogous to that of Charon’s obol and the ''[[Totenpass|Totenpässe]]'' of mystery initiates, and in this case it acts also as a seal to block the dead from returning to the world of the living.<ref>Bonnie Effros, ''Caring for Body and Soul'' (Penn State Press, 2002), p. 45; Effros uses the functional term "viaticum", but the Latin has ''dominicum corpus'' (p. 45, note 12). See also Ernest Babelon, entry on "Danaké," ''Traité des monnaies grecques et romaines'', vol. 1 (Paris: Leroux, 1901), pp. 514–518.</ref>
Ideally, the journey into death would begin immediately after taking the sacrament.<ref>D. Sicard, "Christian Death," in ''The Sacraments'', edited by Robert Cabié, Aime G. Martimort, ''et al.'', translated by Matthew O’Connell (Liturgical Press, 1988), p. 227; G.J.C. Snoek, ''Medieval Piety from Relics to the Eucharist'' (Leiden 1995), p. 117.</ref> [[Eusebius]] offers an example of an elderly Christian who managed to hold off death until his grandson placed a portion of the Eucharist in his mouth.<ref>[[Eusebius]], ''[[Church History (Eusebius)|Historia Ecclesiastica]]'' [http://www.sacred-texts.com/chr/ecf/201/2010214.htm 6.44]; Richard E. DeMaris, "Corinthian Religion and Baptism for the Dead (1 Corinthians 15:29): Insights from Archaeology and Anthropology," ''Journal of Biblical Literature'' 114 (1995), p. 672.</ref> In a general audience October 24, 2007, [[Pope Benedict XVI]] quoted [[Paulinus of Nola|Paulinus]]'s account of the death of [[Ambrose|St. Ambrose]], who received and swallowed the ''corpus Domini'' and immediately "gave up his spirit, taking the good Viaticum with him. His soul, thus refreshed by the virtue of that food, now enjoys the company of [[Angel]]s."<ref>"Saint Ambrose of Milan," [http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/benedict_xvi/audiences/2007/documents/hf_ben-xvi_aud_20071024_en.html general audience], [[St. Peter’s Square]], October 24, 2007.</ref> A perhaps apocryphal story from a [[Cistercians|Cistercian]] chronicle ''circa'' 1200 indicates that the viaticum was regarded as an [[Apotropaic magic|apotropaic]] seal against [[demon]]s (''ad avertendos daemonas''<ref>[[Theodore Balsamon]], ''[[Patrologia Graeca]]'' 137, 794; G.J.C. Snoek, ''Medieval Piety from Relics to the Eucharist'' (Leiden 1995), p. 124.</ref>), who nevertheless induced a woman to attempt to snatch the [[Host (Holy Communion)|Host]] (''viaticum'') from the mouth of [[Pope Urban III]]'s corpse.<ref>[[Ralph Niger|Radulfus Niger]], ''[[Monumenta Germaniae Historica]]: Scriptores rerum Germanicarum'' 27, 336: ''Quo mortuo, sedit ad exequias eius mulier iussu demonum, ut dictum est, prestolans eripere viaticum corporis Domini de ore eius''; G.J.C. Snoek, ''Medieval Piety from Relics to the Eucharist'' (Leiden 1995), p. 124, and p. 374 for more [[Apotropaic magic|apotropaic]] devices against [[Satan]]. See also Bonnie Effros, ''Caring for Body and Soul'' (Penn State Press, 2002), p. 198: "The receipt of the viaticum by the dying was believed to counter the influence of the devil as the soul passed into eternity."</ref> Like Charon's obol, the viaticum can serve as both sustenance for the journey<ref>So too the metaphor of the soul’s food in the account of Ambrose’s death, as emphasized by Pope Benedict, and St. Thomas Aquinas’s reference to the "fruit of God."</ref> and seal.<ref name="John Cuthbert Lawson 1910 pp. 108"/>
In the 19th century, the German scholar [[Georg Heinrici]] proposed that Greek and Roman practices pertaining to the care of the dead, specifically including Charon’s obol, shed light on vicarious baptism, or [[Baptism for the dead#Early history|baptism for the dead]], to which [[Paul the Apostle|St. Paul]] refers in a [[First Epistle to the Corinthians|letter to the Corinthians]].<ref>{{bibleverse|1|Corinthians|15:29|NIV}}.</ref> A century after Heinrici, James Downey examined the funerary practices of [[Corinth#Roman era|Christian Corinthians]] in historical context and argued that they intended vicarious baptism to protect the deceased’s soul against interference on the journey to the afterlife.<ref>C.F.G. Heinrici, ''Das erste Sendschreiben des Apostel Paulus an die Korinthier'' (Berlin 1880), pp. 42–43; James Downey, "1 Cor 15:29 and the Theology of Baptism," ''Euntes Docete'' 38 (1985), pp. 23–25 and 34–35; cited by Richard E. DeMaris, "Corinthian Religion and Baptism for the Dead," ''Journal of Biblical Literature'' 114 (1995), p. 676.</ref> Both vicarious baptism and the placement of a viaticum in the mouth of a person already dead reflect Christian responses to, rather than outright rejection of, ancient religious traditions pertaining to the cult of the dead.<ref>Richard E. DeMaris, "Corinthian Religion and Baptism for the Dead," ''Journal of Biblical Literature'' 114 (1995) 661–682; Mark J. Johnson, "Pagan-Christian Burial Practices of the Fourth Century," ''Journal of Early Christian Studies'' 5 (1997), p. 43. Scholars do not maintain that Christians "borrowed" the rite of communion for the dying from earlier religious practice; the point is more specifically that the communion wafer itself might be used (or misused) in a manner influenced by Charon's obol and the ''lamellae''.</ref>
==Art of the modern era== [[File:Charon and Psyche (cropped).jpg|left|thumb|175px|''Charon and Psyche'' (detail) by [[John Roddam Spencer Stanhope]].<ref>''Charon and Psyche'' is privately owned; published images show two different orientations, with Charon either on the left with his left hand extended, as he is commonly depicted on the lekythoi, or on the right.</ref>]] Although Charon has been a popular subject of art,<ref>[http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Charon_(mythology) Examples.]</ref> particularly in the 19th century, the act of payment is less often depicted. An exception is the ''Charon and Psyche'' of [[John Roddam Spencer Stanhope]], exhibited ''ca.'' 1883. The story of Cupid and Psyche found several expressions among the [[Pre-Raphaelite]] artists and their literary peers,<ref>See [[Charon's obol#Modern poetry|Modern poetry]] following.</ref> and Stanhope, while mourning the death of his only child, produced a number of works dealing with the afterlife. His Psyche paintings were most likely based on the narrative poem of [[William Morris]] that was a retelling of the version by Apuleius.<ref>Nic Peeters and Judy Oberhausen, "L’Arte della memoria: John Roddam Spencer Stanhope and the Tomb of His Daughter Mary," from ''Marble Silence, Words on Stone: [[Florence]]’s [[English Cemetery, Florence|English Cemetery]]'', The City and the Book III International Conference 3–5 June 2004, [http://www.florin.ms/gimeld.html#peetersoberhausen online]; Simon Poë, "Mythology and Symbolism in Two Works of Roddam Spencer Stanhope’s Maturity," ''Journal of Pre-Raphaelite Studies'' 12 (2003) 35–61.</ref> In Stanhope’s vision, the ferryman is a calm and [[wikt:patriarchal|patriarchal]] figure more in keeping with the Charon of the archaic Greek lekythoi than the fearsome antagonist often found in Christian-era art and literature.<ref>Stanhope’s father, also named John, was an explorer and [[antiquarian]], and it is possible that the artist had firsthand knowledge of the archaic Charon from the [[antiquities|artifacts]] his father brought home; see Charles Waldstein, "Discoveries at [[Plataea|Plataia]] in 1890, I. General Report on the Excavations," ''American Journal of Archaeology and of the History of the Fine Arts'' 6 (1890), p. 445.</ref>
The contemporary artist [[Bradley Platz]] extends the theme of Charon’s obol as a [[viaticum|viatical]] food in his [[Oil painting|oil-on-canvas]] work ''Charon and the Shades'' (2007).<ref>Viewable [http://bp2.blogger.com/_EyaM2P3DD7k/RgyevLXY7vI/AAAAAAAAAAY/yremCHNN2RA/s1600-h/bradley+platz.jpg online.]</ref> In this depiction, Charon is a hooded, faceless figure of [[Death (personification)|Death]]; the transported soul regurgitates a stream of gold coins while the penniless struggle and beg on the shores. The painting was created for a show in which artists were to bring together a mythological figure and a [[Popular culture|pop-culture]] [[Cultural icon|icon]], chosen randomly.
